stem: A 55-year-old client with Type 2 Diabetes presents with nausea and kussmaul respirations. Based on the documentation in the Serial Glucose & Metabolic Acidosis Log, what is the most likely diagnosis?

tabs.title: Serum Labs
tabs.content:
TestResultStatus
Serum Glucose168 mg/dLNear Normal
Serum Anion Gap22 mEq/LHigh (Acidosis)
Serum Bicarbonate (HCO3)14 mEq/LLow (Acidosis)
Serum KetonesPositive (Large)Critical

tabs.title: Medication History
tabs.content:
Chronic Meds: Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor), Metformin, Lisinopril.
Recent: Client had a stomach flu and has been unable to eat for 2 days; stopped taking all meds except Empagliflozin.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: Current: Client has 'fruity' odor on breath. Skin is warm and dry. Breath sounds: Rapid and deep (Respirations 28).

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing **Euglycemic Diabetic Ketoacidosis (EDKA) (a1)**. This is a rare form of DKA where the blood glucose is < 250 mg/dL (here it is 168), but the patient is in severe metabolic acidosis with high ketones and a high anion gap. This is a known risk for patients taking **SGLT2 inhibitors** (like Empagliflozin), as these drugs increase glucose excretion in the urine, keeping the blood sugar 'masked' as normal even while the body is starving and producing lethal ketones.
clinicalPearls: SGLT2 inhibitors ('-gliflozin' drugs) can cause DKA even if the sugar looks fine.
Check ketones/vitals, not just sugar, in symptomatic patients on -gliflozin drugs.
Treatment is the same as DKA: IV Insulin and Dextrose-containing fluids immediately.

questionTrap.trap: Ruling out DKA because the glucose is 168 (Normal < 200).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the patient has **Fruity Breath**, **Kussmaul breathing**, or **Positive Ketones**, it is DKA regardless of what the glucose says. Always check the medication list for an SGLT2 inhibitor.

mnemonic.title: Normal Nasty
mnemonic.expansion: Normally looking sugar (160s). Nastily high ketones. (EDKA).
